komm: Regional administrative boundaries define the specific climatic and regulatory environment for the crop.
nedbarea: Local precipitation patterns dictate seasonal water availability and potential nitrogen leaching.
jordtype: Physical soil composition determines water retention capacity and the availability of essential nutrients.
nmin: Residual mineral nitrogen present in the soil profile at planting serves as the initial nutrient supply.
aar_mod: Seasonal weather variations alter the maturation timeline and grain quality outcomes compared to average years.
potnmin: Microbial mineralization potential estimates the expected release of nitrogen from organic matter during growth.
forfrugt: Identity of the previous crop influences soil nitrogen legacy and the risk of carry-over soil pathogens.
jordn: Total organic and inorganic nitrogen within the soil matrix represents the underlying nutrient reservoir.
exptgens: Specific management protocols used in research trials differentiate these samples from standard commercial crops.
pesticid: Applied chemical treatments protect the crop canopy from fungal diseases and pest-induced yield loss.
mod_nmin: Estimated mineral nitrogen levels account for early-season leaching and the dynamics of soil organic matter release.
ngodnt: Cumulative nitrogen dosage across all split applications sets the physiological ceiling for protein synthesis.
nopt: Ideal nitrogen application rate maximizes financial returns while satisfying malting quality requirements.
ngodnn: Net synthetic fertilizer input acts as the primary tool for correcting early-season nitrogen deficiencies.
ngodn: Nitrogen application units drive the intensity of vegetative development and canopy health.
nprot: Total nitrogen accumulation in the grain tissue dictates the potential for enzyme synthesis during malting.
rokap: Maximum rooting depth restricts the volume of soil from which the barley can extract water and mobile nutrients.
saatid: Calendar date of sowing establishes the thermal window and day-length conditions available for development.
dgv1059: Thermal accumulation during early vegetative stages (BBCH 10-59) dictates the timing of flowering.
sort: Selected cultivar genetics determine the inherent potential for yield, protein, and disease resistance.
srtprot: Variety-specific nitrogen uptake efficiency characterizes the genetic potential for grain protein accumulation.
dg25: Occurrence of temperatures above 25°C during grain filling induces stress and potentially reduces kernel weight.
ngtilg: Combined nitrogen supply from soil reserves and fertilization determines the ceiling for biomass production.
nplac: Sub-surface placement of fertilizer near the seed facilitates rapid nutrient uptake and early plant vigor.
ntilg: Active nitrogen availability throughout the growth cycle regulates the metabolic balance between yield and protein.
saamng: Sowing mass per hectare dictates the initial density of the plant stand and resource competition.
saakern: Planned kernel count per square meter provides the foundation for spikes per unit area.
tkvs: Seed lot thousand-kernel weight influences the initial energy reserves available for successful seedling emergence.
frspdag: Time elapsed between sowing and emergence reflects the combined influence of soil temperature and moisture.
jordinf: Soil-borne fungal pressure impairs root function and reduces the efficiency of nutrient and water uptake.
partigerm: Certified viability of the seed source determines the maximum achievable plant population.
markgrm: Field-level emergence success accounts for seedbed quality and environmental challenges at planting.
antplnt: Established number of plants per square meter determines the potential for tiller development.
sorttkv: Genetic benchmark for thousand-kernel weight provides an expected value for grain size under optimal conditions.
aks_m2: Density of fertile spikes per unit area serves as a primary driver of grain yield.
keraks: Kernel count per individual spike reflects pollination success and nutrient supply during flowering.
dgv5980: Heat units accumulated during the late reproductive window (BBCH 59-80) control the duration of grain maturation.
aks_vgt: Dry matter weight of individual spikes reflects the efficiency of resource translocation to the grain.
srtsize: Inherent kernel dimension traits of the selected cultivar influence the likelihood of meeting size-based quality grades.
ksort: Grading of kernels exceeding 2.5 mm determines the batch's commercial value for malting.
protein: Nitrogen concentration in the harvested kernels governs the extract potential and foam stability of the final beer.
udb: Grain yield per hectare integrates the cumulative effectiveness of environmental factors and management decisions.
spndx: Leaf chlorophyll readings provide a real-time proxy for nitrogen status and photosynthetic vigor.
tkv: Harvested thousand-kernel mass serves as a proxy for the effectiveness of the grain-filling period.
slt22: Undersized grains measuring less than 2.2 mm represent screenings usually diverted from malt production to animal feed.
s2225: Intermediate grain fraction between 2.2 and 2.5 mm impacts the homogeneity of the germination process.
s2528: Premium grain size range from 2.5 to 2.8 mm offers the most consistent malting performance.
bgbyg_: Categorical quality assessment for malting barley synthesizes kernel size, protein content, and germination vigor.
